title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 18 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Chronicles chapter 18 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 18 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Chronicles Chapter 18.

questions.question: Whom did David smite and subdue, according to 1 Chronicles 18:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:1 states that David smote the Philistines and subdued them.

questions.question: What did the Moabites become to David after he smote them, as mentioned in 1 Chronicles 18:2?
questions.correctAnswer: David's servants
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:2 says the Moabites became David's servants and brought gifts.

questions.question: Who was the king of Zobah that David smote, according to 1 Chronicles 18:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Hadarezer
questions.explanation: The verse 1 Chronicles 18:3 identifies Hadarezer as the king of Zobah whom David smote.

questions.question: How many chariots did David take from Hadarezer, as recorded in 1 Chronicles 18:4?
questions.correctAnswer: One thousand
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:4 states that David took a thousand chariots from Hadarezer.

questions.question: How many men did David kill from the Syrians of Damascus when they helped Hadarezer, according to 1 Chronicles 18:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-two thousand
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:5 mentions David slew twenty-two thousand Syrians of Damascus.

questions.question: What did David do after he put garrisons in Syria Damascus, as per 1 Chronicles 18:6?
options: The Syrians became David's servants and brought gifts
questions.correctAnswer: The Syrians became David's servants and brought gifts
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:6 states after garrisons were put in Syria Damascus, the Syrians became David's servants and brought gifts.

questions.question: What did David take from the servants of Hadarezer and bring to Jerusalem, according to 1 Chronicles 18:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Shields of gold
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:7 says David took the shields of gold from Hadarezer's servants and brought them to Jerusalem.

questions.question: From which cities did David bring much brass used later by Solomon, as mentioned in 1 Chronicles 18:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Tibhath and Chun
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:8 states that David brought much brass from the cities Tibhath and Chun of Hadarezer.

questions.question: Who was the king of Hamath that heard about David's victory over Hadarezer, according to 1 Chronicles 18:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Tou
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:9 identifies Tou as the king of Hamath who heard about David's victory.

questions.question: Who did King Tou send to David to congratulate him, as noted in 1 Chronicles 18:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Hadoram his son
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:10 says Tou sent his son Hadoram to king David to congratulate him.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Chronicles 18:12, Abishai killed eighteen thousand Edomites in the valley of salt.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:12 records that Abishai slew eighteen thousand Edomites in the valley of salt.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Chronicles 18:14 states David was a weak ruler who did not execute justice.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:14 says David reigned over all Israel and executed judgment and justice among his people.

questions.question: True or False: Joab was over the host during David's reign, as mentioned in 1 Chronicles 18:15.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:15 states Joab the son of Zeruiah was over the host.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the ______ and the Pelethites;' (1 Chronicles 18:17)
questions.correctAnswer: Cherethites
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:17 states Benaiah was over the Cherethites and the Pelethites.

questions.question: Who were the priests mentioned in 1 Chronicles 18:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Zadok and Abimelech
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:16 mentions Zadok son of Ahitub and Abimelech son of Abiathar as the priests.

medium.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 18 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Chronicles Chapter 18 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 1 Chronicles 18, what biblical truth would you share about God's faithfulness?
options: God preserves and protects His people wherever they go.
God allows His people to be defeated if they are not strong.
God only helps when battles are fought physically.
God's protection depends on human strength alone.
questions.correctAnswer: God preserves and protects His people wherever they go.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:6 and 18:13 show that the LORD preserved David wherever he went, demonstrating God's faithfulness and protection in trials.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 18 teach us about humility in leadership?
options: David acknowledges that victories come from the LORD's help.
David takes full credit for all his conquests without mentioning God.
David relies solely on his military strategies.
David refuses to share his spoils with others.
questions.correctAnswer: David acknowledges that victories come from the LORD's help.
questions.explanation: The repeated statement in 1 Chronicles 18:6 and 18:13 that the LORD preserved David whithersoever he went shows David's humility in recognizing God's role in his successes.

questions.question: What does David’s treatment of the chariot horses teach about integrity and responsibility in work, based on 1 Chronicles 18?
options: David disabled the horses to prevent enemies from using them but kept a hundred for his own use.
David destroyed all captured horses without exception.
David sold all the horses for profit.
David abandoned the horses in enemy territory.
questions.correctAnswer: David disabled the horses to prevent enemies from using them but kept a hundred for his own use.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:4 shows David 'houghed' (disabled) the chariot horses to prevent their use by enemies but kept a hundred, demonstrating wise stewardship and responsibility in handling resources.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with gratitude after receiving blessings. How does David’s response to spoils of war in 1 Chronicles 18 encourage a spirit of gratitude and stewardship?
options: David dedicated silver and gold from conquered nations to the LORD.
David kept all the treasures for personal use.
David ignored God in his acquisitions.
David gave gifts only to his family.
questions.correctAnswer: David dedicated silver and gold from conquered nations to the LORD.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:11 emphasizes David’s dedication of riches from various nations to the LORD, teaching gratitude and faithful stewardship of blessings.

questions.question: What example does 1 Chronicles 18 provide about the importance of faithful service in the church or community?
options: David appointed specific leaders and priests to serve in their roles faithfully.
David managed all duties himself without delegation.
David ignored leadership roles in the community.
David appointed leaders based on favoritism.
questions.correctAnswer: David appointed specific leaders and priests to serve in their roles faithfully.
questions.explanation: Verses 15-17 show David appointing Joab, Jehoshaphat, Zadok, Abimelech, and others to serve specific roles, demonstrating the value of faithful service and order in the community.

questions.question: How does David’s victory over various nations teach us about perseverance and trust in God during difficult tasks?
options: David continually trusted the LORD and succeeded in battle.
David gave up after the first defeat.
David relied on human strength alone.
questions.correctAnswer: David continually trusted the LORD and succeeded in battle.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18 records multiple victories (Philistines, Moab, Hadarezer, Syrians, Edom) with the repeated theme of the LORD preserving David (verses 6 and 13), highlighting perseverance through trust in God.

questions.question: What does the sending of gifts by conquered peoples to David teach about generosity and reconciliation?
options: Conquered peoples became servants and brought gifts, showing submission and peace.
Conquered peoples continued to fight without reconciliation.
David refused gifts to maintain distance.
David punished all conquered peoples without mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: Conquered peoples became servants and brought gifts, showing submission and peace.
questions.explanation: Verses 2, 6, and 10 show Moabites, Syrians, and Hamath sending gifts and acknowledging David’s rule, teaching about reconciliation and generosity in relationships after conflict.

questions.question: True or False: David executed judgment and justice over all Israel during his reign.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:14 states that David reigned over all Israel and executed judgment and justice among all his people, emphasizing righteous leadership.

questions.question: True or False: David kept all the spoils from his victories for himself and his family only.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:11 shows that David dedicated silver and gold from various nations to the LORD, indicating he did not keep all spoils for personal use but honored God with them.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: David put garrisons in _________, and all the people became his servants, showing strategic faithfulness in leadership.
questions.correctAnswer: Edom
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:13 mentions David putting garrisons in Edom and the Edomites becoming servants, showing strategic leadership combined with faith in God's preservation.

questions.question: How does the example of Abishai’s victory over Edomites encourage believers facing spiritual battles?
options: Faithful service and courage in the Lord lead to victory.
Relying only on human strength ensures success.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful service and courage in the Lord lead to victory.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:12 shows Abishai’s courage in slaying 18,000 Edomites, illustrating that faithful service and reliance on God bring victory in trials.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is shown by David’s dedication of spoils from Edom, Moab, Ammon, Philistines, and Amalek to the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Generosity and gratitude toward God.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:11 highlights David dedicating silver and gold from many nations to the LORD, demonstrating generosity and gratitude in stewardship.

questions.question: What does the sending of Hadoram by King Tou to David teach about the importance of fellowship and peace among believers?
options: It shows the value of congratulating and establishing peaceful relations.
It promotes isolation from other nations.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the value of congratulating and establishing peaceful relations.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:10 records King Tou sending his son to congratulate David, showing the importance of fellowship and peace among nations and believers.

questions.question: In the context of family life, what does the appointment of David’s sons as chiefs around the king teach us?
options: Entrusting family members with responsibilities fosters unity and wise leadership.
Family members should avoid leadership roles.
Leadership should exclude family to prevent favoritism.
Family should be kept separate from matters of state.
questions.correctAnswer: Entrusting family members with responsibilities fosters unity and wise leadership.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:17 mentions David’s sons were chief about the king, illustrating trust and responsibility within family leadership roles.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 18 encourage believers to maintain integrity in their work and leadership?
options: By appointing faithful leaders and maintaining order in governance.
By ignoring responsibilities and delegating poorly.
By acting selfishly and taking all credit.
questions.correctAnswer: By appointing faithful leaders and maintaining order in governance.
questions.explanation: Verses 15-17 show David appointing qualified leaders and priests, emphasizing integrity and accountability in leadership and work.

hard.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 18 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Chronicles Chapter 18.

questions.question: Which city and its towns did David capture from the Philistines after his victory?
questions.correctAnswer: Gath
questions.explanation: David smote the Philistines and took Gath and her towns from their control, as stated in 1 Chronicles 18:1.

questions.question: What was the relationship between Moab and David following his conquest?
options: Moabites became David's servants and brought gifts
Moabites formed an alliance with David
questions.correctAnswer: Moabites became David's servants and brought gifts
questions.explanation: After David smote Moab, the Moabites became his servants and brought gifts, indicating subjugation and tribute, as recorded in 1 Chronicles 18:2.

questions.question: David defeated Hadarezer king of Zobah as he tried to establish dominion by which river?
questions.correctAnswer: Euphrates
questions.explanation: Hadarezer was extending his dominion by the river Euphrates when David smote him, as noted in 1 Chronicles 18:3.

questions.question: How many chariots did David take from Hadarezer, and what did he do to most of the chariot horses?
options: Took 1,000 chariots and houghed all chariot horses except 100
Took 500 chariots and kept all horses
Took 1,500 chariots and gave horses to allies
Took 2,000 chariots and sold the horses
questions.correctAnswer: Took 1,000 chariots and houghed all chariot horses except 100
questions.explanation: David took 1,000 chariots from Hadarezer but disabled (houghed) all the horses except 100, as detailed in 1 Chronicles 18:4. This shows strategic control over enemy resources.

questions.question: The defeat of which Syrian city led the Syrians to become David's servants and bring him gifts?
questions.correctAnswer: Damascus
questions.explanation: After defeating the Syrians of Damascus who came to help Hadarezer, David put garrisons in Damascus, and the Syrians became his servants (1 Chronicles 18:5-6).

questions.question: What significance does the brass taken from Tibhath and Chun have in the broader biblical narrative?
options: Used by Solomon to make the brazen sea and pillars
Used by David to build his palace
Given as a gift to the temple priests
questions.correctAnswer: Used by Solomon to make the brazen sea and pillars
questions.explanation: The brass from Tibhath and Chun was used by Solomon to craft the brazen sea, pillars, and other vessels, showing continuity between David’s conquests and Solomon’s temple construction (1 Chronicles 18:8).

questions.question: How did Tou king of Hamath respond to David's victory over Hadarezer?
options: Sent his son Hadoram with gifts and congratulations
questions.correctAnswer: Sent his son Hadoram with gifts and congratulations
questions.explanation: Tou sent his son Hadoram to David to congratulate him and bring gifts, recognizing David's military success over Hadarezer (1 Chronicles 18:9-10).

questions.question: Which nations contributed silver and gold that David dedicated to the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Edom, Moab, Ammon, Philistines, Amalek
questions.explanation: David dedicated silver and gold from Edom, Moab, Ammon, Philistines, and Amalek to the LORD, showing the extent of his dominion and tribute (1 Chronicles 18:11).

questions.question: Who was responsible for slaying eighteen thousand Edomites in the valley of salt?
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai son of Zeruiah
questions.explanation: Abishai, David’s nephew and son of Zeruiah, killed eighteen thousand Edomites in the valley of salt, a significant military feat noted in 1 Chronicles 18:12.

questions.question: True or False: David left the Edomites independent after his campaign in the valley of salt.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David placed garrisons in Edom, and the Edomites became his servants, indicating they were subjugated and not left independent (1 Chronicles 18:13).

questions.question: What roles did Joab and Jehoshaphat hold during David’s reign as recorded in this chapter?
options: Joab over the host; Jehoshaphat recorder
questions.correctAnswer: Joab over the host; Jehoshaphat recorder
questions.explanation: Joab was commander of the army, and Jehoshaphat was the recorder, reflecting the military and administrative structure under David (1 Chronicles 18:15).

questions.question: Which two individuals served as priests during David’s reign according to this chapter?
options: Zadok son of Ahitub and Abimelech son of Abiathar
questions.correctAnswer: Zadok son of Ahitub and Abimelech son of Abiathar
questions.explanation: The priests serving were Zadok son of Ahitub and Abimelech son of Abiathar, indicating a dual priesthood during David’s time (1 Chronicles 18:16).

questions.question: Who oversaw the Cherethites and Pelethites, the king’s personal guards?
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah son of Jehoiada
questions.explanation: Benaiah was over the Cherethites and Pelethites, elite guards serving closely with the king (1 Chronicles 18:17).

questions.question: The repeated phrase 'Thus the LORD preserved David whithersoever he went' emphasizes which theological theme?
options: Divine providence and favor upon David’s military campaigns
David’s own military genius as sole cause of success
The futility of war without God
questions.correctAnswer: Divine providence and favor upon David’s military campaigns
questions.explanation: The phrase highlights that David’s successes were due to the LORD’s preservation, stressing divine providence and favor (1 Chronicles 18:6, 18:13).

questions.question: How does the military success of David in this chapter foreshadow the later expansion of Israel in the biblical narrative?
options: It sets the foundation for Solomon’s peaceful and prosperous reign
It shows the limits of Israel’s power beyond the Jordan
It predicts the exile and return of Israel
It indicates the division of the kingdom after David
questions.correctAnswer: It sets the foundation for Solomon’s peaceful and prosperous reign
questions.explanation: David’s conquests and the accumulation of materials and wealth foreshadow the stability and temple-building of Solomon’s reign (1 Chronicles 18:8, 18:11).

theological.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 18 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Chronicles Chapter 18 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the significance of David smiting the Philistines and taking Gath and her towns according to 1 Chronicles 18?
options: It demonstrated God's providential protection over Israel
It was a political alliance with the Philistines
It showed David's failure to trust God
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrated God's providential protection over Israel
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:1 shows David's victory over the Philistines as a demonstration of God's providential care, consistent with God's protection seen in Exodus 14:14, Psalm 20:7, Isaiah 41:10, Romans 8:31, and 2 Chronicles 20:15.

questions.question: How did the Moabites respond after David smote them?
options: They became David's servants and brought gifts
They formed an alliance against Israel
They fled to the mountains and resisted
questions.correctAnswer: They became David's servants and brought gifts
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:2 describes the Moabites submitting to David, echoing biblical themes of divine sovereignty and submission found in Psalm 72:9, Isaiah 60:14, Philippians 2:10-11, Romans 14:11, and Hebrews 12:28.

questions.question: What military spoils did David take from Hadarezer king of Zobah?
options: A thousand chariots, seven thousand horsemen, and twenty thousand footmen
Five hundred chariots and three thousand horsemen
questions.correctAnswer: A thousand chariots, seven thousand horsemen, and twenty thousand footmen
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:4 states the spoils taken, illustrating God's blessing on David's reign, consistent with God's promises of victory in Deuteronomy 20:4, Joshua 10:14, Psalm 18:39, Isaiah 41:10, and Romans 8:37.

questions.question: Why did David 'houghed' the chariot horses except for a hundred?
options: To disable the enemy's chariots and prevent their use
To keep all chariots for his own army
To sacrifice them to the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: To disable the enemy's chariots and prevent their use
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:4 shows David incapacitating most chariot horses to neutralize enemy strength, reflecting God's judgment on human militarism in Isaiah 31:1, Psalm 20:7, Jeremiah 46:3, Ezekiel 39:9, and Revelation 19:11.

questions.question: How many Syrian men did David kill when they came to help Hadarezer?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-two thousand
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:5 records twenty-two thousand Syrians slain, demonstrating God's enabling power in battle, consistent with Exodus 15:6, Judges 7:22, 2 Samuel 5:10, Psalm 44:3, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: What was the result of David placing garrisons in Syria-Damascus?
options: The Syrians became David's servants and brought gifts
The Syrians formed a coalition against David
The garrisons were destroyed by the Syrians
There was no change in the relationship
questions.correctAnswer: The Syrians became David's servants and brought gifts
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:6 shows submission and tribute from the Syrians, reflecting God's sovereign rule and blessing, paralleled in Psalm 72:8, Isaiah 60:14, Jeremiah 27:6, Romans 14:11, and Revelation 15:4.

questions.question: What did David do with the golden shields taken from Hadarezer's servants?
options: He melted them down for coins
He gave them to the priests as offerings
questions.correctAnswer: He brought them to Jerusalem
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:7 states David took the shields to Jerusalem, symbolizing God's provision and the centrality of worship, consistent with Exodus 25:11, 2 Samuel 6:12, Psalm 48:1-2, Isaiah 2:3, and Hebrews 12:22.

questions.question: What significance do the brass items from Tibhath and Chun have in the biblical narrative?
options: They were used by Solomon to make the brazen sea and pillars
They were sold to fund David's army
They were given as gifts to surrounding nations
They were used to build David's palace
questions.correctAnswer: They were used by Solomon to make the brazen sea and pillars
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:8 connects David's conquests to Solomon's temple construction, illustrating God's covenant fulfillment, consistent with Exodus 37:17-24, 1 Kings 7:23-26, 2 Chronicles 4:2-5, Psalm 132:13-14, and John 2:19.

questions.question: Why did King Tou of Hamath send his son to King David?
options: To enquire of his welfare and congratulate him for defeating Hadarezer
To seek an alliance against the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: To enquire of his welfare and congratulate him for defeating Hadarezer
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:9-10 describes this diplomatic act, demonstrating recognition of David's God-ordained victories, consistent with Genesis 41:40, 2 Samuel 10:5, Psalm 2:6-9, Isaiah 45:1, and Romans 13:1.

questions.question: What did David do with the silver and gold he brought from the nations he defeated?
options: He dedicated them to the LORD
He kept them for personal wealth
He gave them to the army
He buried them in the ground
questions.correctAnswer: He dedicated them to the LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:11 shows David's dedication of spoils to God, highlighting worship and stewardship, consistent with Exodus 35:21, 1 Chronicles 29:14, Psalm 96:8, Isaiah 60:6, and Hebrews 13:16.

questions.question: Who was responsible for killing eighteen thousand Edomites in the valley of salt?
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai the son of Zeruiah
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:12 credits Abishai with this victory, illustrating God working through His leaders, consistent with Judges 7:20, 2 Samuel 23:18, Psalm 144:1, Isaiah 41:13, and Romans 13:4.

questions.question: What was the spiritual significance of the LORD preserving David wherever he went?
options: It affirmed God's sovereign protection over His anointed king
It meant David was invincible and without sin
It showed that David was the ultimate savior
It indicated God's judgment on Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It affirmed God's sovereign protection over His anointed king
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Chronicles 18:6 and 18:13 emphasize God's preservation of David, reflecting God's covenant faithfulness, consistent with Psalm 23:4, Isaiah 41:10, Jeremiah 1:8, Acts 13:22, and Romans 8:28.

questions.question: Who served as the recorder during David's reign as noted in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:15 identifies Jehoshaphat as recorder, a role affirming orderly governance, consistent with Exodus 24:4, Nehemiah 7:5, 2 Kings 18:18, Luke 1:2, and Revelation 5:1.

questions.question: Who was put over the Cherethites and the Pelethites during David's reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:17 shows Benaiah's leadership, illustrating God's provision of faithful servants, consistent with 2 Samuel 23:20-23, Psalm 78:72, Proverbs 11:14, Acts 6:3, and Ephesians 4:11.

questions.question: What core doctrine is illustrated by David executing judgment and justice among all his people?
options: The righteous rule of God through His anointed king
The separation of church and state
The necessity of warfare for peace
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous rule of God through His anointed king
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 18:14 shows David's just reign, reflecting God's justice in governance, consistent with Deuteronomy 16:18-20, Psalm 72:1-4, Isaiah 9:6-7, Jeremiah 23:5-6, and Romans 13:1-4.
